Inaugural 47-Centimeter Flight Declared 'Magnificent' By All Three Passengers

By Roger Crumbly, Founder, CEO, Pilot, and Head of Compliment Verification • Tuesday

History was made this past Saturday at approximately 2:47 PM when Sky Schmaltz Flight 001 successfully traversed the entire length of my kitchen island, from the toaster oven to the paper towel holder, in what aviation experts are calling "technically a thing that happened."

The three passengers—a 1:12 scale figurine of Amelia Earhart, a button shaped like my late Uncle Murray, and a compliment written on a Post-it note ("Roger, your meatloaf is not as dry as Linda always said")—all arrived at their destination unharmed and, in my professional estimation, visibly moved.

The flight was powered by 347 compliments, collected over a six-month period from dental patients, my mother (under duress), and one remarkably generous Walgreens cashier named Patrice. Headwinds from the ceiling fan added 12 compliments to the final cost, which I absorbed personally because I believe in customer service.

Critics will note that the biplane briefly struck a salt shaker during descent. I would remind those critics that the Wright Brothers also had setbacks, and nobody accused them of "playing with toys during a custody hearing."

Linda's attorney has requested I stop mentioning her name in press releases. I have respectfully declined, as she remains the inspiration for our entire fleet of flight attendant uniforms. The pencil skirts are exact replicas. I measured.

Our next flight is scheduled for March, weather permitting. By "weather" I mean my emotional state, which is currently classified as "partly cloudy with intermittent sobbing."

Big Compliment Is Watching: An Investigation

An editorial by Roger Crumbly • Part 7 of an ongoing series

I'm going to say what nobody in Skokie has the courage to say: Hallmark is running a compliment cartel. They have monopolized sincere human expression and repackaged it as a $4.99 card with a cartoon dog saying "You're Paw-some!" That dog is a puppet. Follow the money.

For three years, I have submitted my airline's compliment-based fare structure to the Federal Aviation Administration. For three years, they have responded with the same form letter stating that "feelings are not a recognized unit of propulsion." Interesting choice of words, FAA. Very interesting. Almost as if someone told them to say that.

Last month, I attended a Hallmark shareholders' meeting disguised as a gift bag. What I heard confirmed my worst suspicions: they are aware of Sky Schmaltz. They have a file. The file is labeled "CRUMBLY — LOW PRIORITY." Low priority. As if democratizing human warmth is a low priority.

"They want you to buy the card. They don't want you to BE the card." — Roger Crumbly, at a Denny's, 2:30 AM

I have obtained documents—and by "obtained" I mean I overheard Carol at the mini-golf course talking to her sister—that suggest Globo-Shame Airlines is partially funded by Big Greeting Card. Their CEO, a man known only as "Mr. Transaction," reportedly described compliments as "non-monetizable sentiment waste." I wept when I heard this. I wept again typing it just now.

The evidence is circumstantial but emotionally overwhelming. Consider: Why does every Walgreens have an entire aisle dedicated to pre-written sentiments? Because the system doesn't want you to generate your own. It wants you dependent. It wants you reaching for a card that says "Thinking of You" instead of walking up to someone and saying, "Harold, your lawn edging is immaculate and I see you."

I see you, Harold. I always have.

Sky Schmaltz is not just an airline. It is a resistance movement. Every compliment is a vote against the pre-packaged emotional industrial complex. Every 47-centimeter flight is a middle finger to Globo-Shame and their bloodless, receipt-based worldview.

They will try to stop me. They have tried. Linda's attorney sent another letter. My mother suggested I "maybe try a hobby that doesn't alarm the neighbors." But I will not be silenced. Not while there are lasagnas going un-praised. Not while Gary still hasn't returned my call.

Corrections & Clarifications

Issue #13: We stated that Globo-Shame Airlines was "a soulless husk of transactional despair." Globo-Shame's legal team has informed us this is defamatory. We have amended our position: Globo-Shame Airlines is "an allegedly soulless husk of transactional despair." We regret the omission.

Issue #13: The article "Roger's Top 10 Compliments of 2024" incorrectly listed compliment #4 as "You have a nice smile, Roger" when it was in fact "You have a nice smile, Robert." Roger is not Robert. This error caused significant emotional damage and a 2-day grounding of the entire fleet.

Issue #12: We reported that Roger's meatloaf won "Best in Skokie." There is no such award. Roger created the award. The trophy is a painted golf ball. We stand by the sentiment.

Issue #11: The photo captioned "Roger with a satisfied customer" was actually Roger with a mannequin from the former mini-golf pro shop. The mannequin has since been promoted to Chief Morale Officer.

Frequently Asked Questions

Updated bi-weekly by Roger, personally

Do the planes actually fly? +
Define "fly." If you mean "move through the air under their own power for a sustained period," then no. If you mean "briefly achieve a state of altitude that could, under the right emotional conditions, be described as flight," then also no. But they glide. They glide beautifully. For up to 3 seconds.
Is this a real airline? +
Sky Schmaltz is as real as the feelings that power it. We are not currently recognized by the FAA, IATA, or my homeowner's association. But neither was love, at first.
Who is Linda? +
Linda is a concept. Linda represents anyone who has ever looked at someone's meatloaf and said "it's dry" instead of "thank you for trying." We are all Linda sometimes. But some of us are more Linda than others. Specifically, Linda.
Is Hallmark really suppressing genuine connection? +
I have compiled a 340-page dossier that I cannot share for legal reasons. What I can say is this: the next time you're in a Walgreens, count the greeting cards. Now count the number of those cards that say something you couldn't have just said to the person yourself. That's not convenience. That's a supply chain of emotional outsourcing. Wake up.
Can I pay in dollars? +
Absolutely not. Dollars are the language of Globo-Shame. We accept compliments, heartfelt observations, and on Tuesdays, casseroles. If you attempt to pay in cash, you will be escorted from the windmill by our Head of Security (a scarecrow named Phil that I dressed in my old dental scrubs).
Why are you doing this, Roger? +
In 2017, I overheard a boy tell his mother her lasagna was "okay." Just "okay." Not "Mom, this lasagna is a warm hug from the universe" or "This is the best thing that has ever happened to my mouth." Just "okay." I went home that night and I built a plane. I don't know why. I just knew that the world needed more. More than "okay." More than "fine." More than whatever Linda's attorney keeps calling "a healthy distance." We deserve magnificent.
